name: Jameschengalloneword.GitHub.io
body:
### Welcome to GitHub Pages.
This automatic page generator is the easiest way to create beautiful pages for all of your projects. Author your page content here using GitHub Flavored Markdown, select a template crafted by a designer, and publish. After your page is generated, you can check out the new branch:

```
$ cd your_repo_root/repo_name
$ git fetch origin
$ git checkout gh-pages
```

If you're using the GitHub for Mac, simply sync your repository and you'll see the new branch.

### Designer Templates
We've crafted some handsome templates for you to use. Go ahead and continue to layouts to browse through them. You can easily go back to edit your page before publishing. After publishing your page, you can revisit the page generator and switch to another theme. Your Page content will be preserved if it remained markdown format.

### Rather Drive Stick?
If you prefer to not use the automatic generator, push a branch named `gh-pages` to your repository to create a page manually. In addition to supporting regular HTML content, GitHub Pages support Jekyll, a simple, blog aware static site generator written by our own Tom Preston-Werner. Jekyll makes it easy to create site-wide headers and footers without having to copy them across every page. It also offers intelligent blog support and other advanced templating features.

### Authors and Contributors
You can @mention a GitHub username to generate a link to their profile. The resulting `<a>` element will link to the contributor's GitHub Profile. For example: In 2007, Chris Wanstrath (@defunkt), PJ Hyett (@pjhyett), and Tom Preston-Werner (@mojombo) founded GitHub.

### Support or Contact
Having trouble with Pages? Check out the documentation at https://help.github.com/pages or contact support@github.com and we’ll help you sort it out.

### Resume
James Cheng  

8802 Colonial Dr., Austin, TX 78758  

james.cheng@utexas.edu ■ (719) 209-7182  


### Education
The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas

GPA: 3.91

May 2012
Bachelor of Arts, Neuroscience

### Work Experience
Student Technician
Dr. James Howison, The University of Texas at Austin	Sep. 2014 – current
•	Provided technical assistance on the creation of an online Virtual Organization Resources and Toolkits Exchange, such as building a prototype website and developing visualizations of the content
•	Liaison with Science of Team Science Toolkit members in order to add content as needed
Graduate Research Assistant
Center for Transportation Research Library, The University of Texas at Austin	June 2014 – current
•	Provided reference for the UT, Texas Department of Transportation, and greater communities through duties such as literature searches, obtaining research materials, and instruction on searching databases
•	Assisted with technical services such as quality control and maintenance of the catalog, processing new materials, and collection management
•	Worked on special projects as needed, such as digitization, reclassification, and managing social media
•	Performed circulation tasks such as stacks maintenance, shelving, and shelf reading
Research Assistant
Dr. James Howison, The University of Texas at Austin	March 2014 – May 2014
•	Traced the career paths of former employees of the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois through LinkedIn and other internet sources in order to investigate evidence of cyber infrastructure diaspora
•	Created interactive online data visualizations using d3.js and co-wrote final report on the study
Paraprofessional
Office of the Dean, Colorado College	Sep. 2012 – June 2013
•	Conducted statistical research for the Dean’s office, such as analyzing 5 year trends in faculty sabbaticals, annual faculty visitor reports, and three year faculty teaching and student load
•	Supervised the Transitions Fellowship Program: fundraised approximately $30,000 awarded for projects and internships for recent Colorado College graduates, assembled and headed the selection committee, collected and reviewed applications, publicized and reported on the program
•	Prepared drafts and memos for the Dean’s office
•	Scheduled and coordinated spaces and event planning
•	Managed the Rosetta Stone Language Program, organized enrollment and access of approximately 70 faculty and staff users, performed troubleshooting for the program, conducted statistical research and reporting on usage
•	Provided web site support with dotcms content management system
Student Research Assistant 
Office of Institutional Research, Colorado College	Aug. 2010 – May 2012
•	Analyzed 5 year trends in student drop out/stop out rates and qualitative reasons
•	Created reports for Colorado College’s statistical profile 
•	Digitized records for future use and analysis
•	Provided analysis on strategic planning data collection and data support for campus  committees and offices
Student Supervisor
Tutt Library Circulation Desk, Colorado College	Aug. 2008 – May 2012
•	Supervised student workers during the weekends and in absence of senior supervising staff 
•	Helped patrons with minor reference questions and training with library services and facilities 
•	Performed duties such as opening and closing the library, maintained interlibrary loans, reserves, and holds, shelving, shelf reading, searching, monitoring, and shifting

Bridge Program Mentor 
Office of Summer Programs, Colorado College	Aug. 2009 – May 2011
•	Organized and planned events for approximately 40 incoming first generation, international, and minority students
•	Mentored and advised students with academic work and social lives through the academic year

### Other Activities
iSchool Curriculum Committee Member
•	Provided master’s student perspective on curricular issues such as core curriculum descriptions, policies on adjuncts, and analysis of teaching loads.
	Sep. 2013 – current

Colorado College STRIPES Program
•	Alumni admissions volunteer for Colorado College: interviewed prospective students for admission, attended college fairs and admitted student receptions, publically spoke about personal experiences with Colorado College
	Sep. 2012 – June 2013

Midstates Undergraduate Research Symposium
•	Presented research in a poster session about Colorado College LGBT organizations and campus satisfaction	Oct. 2009

American Library Association Spectrum Scholarship (National Library of Medicine / Medical Library Association Scholar) – $5,000 scholarship	2013 – 2014
